Transcription for 1876111

Heinz was always far more interested than I in analyzing work and his always had a psychological slant,
that is it had to reflect some very consciously inner states of mind. It sounds ghastly if I say it like that,
but he was very introspective and very analytical about everything, not just his work.
He had very delicate hands and delicate fingers and his work had the same delicacy and I thought it was quite unique.
We both felt that because of our background and everything that had happened that we were outsiders
and that we couldn't somehow be accepted by the art establishment.
Then he bought an old farm in Wales and finally he left teaching and settled in Wales on that farm
and turned it into his own little empire where he produced very interesting and intricate paintings that I liked very much.
